conversation.content: [very quietly] They told me I'd be interviewing someone named Pat Morrison about the nutrition program, but they didn't mention— [pause] I didn't realize it would be you.

[hesitantly] Your editor called last week and said they were sending their best technical writer to document the whole system we built here. [clearing throat] When they said the name, I thought maybe it was someone else with the same last name.

[monotone] We should probably focus on the program documentation since that's why the magazine sent me here. [quietly] The automated meal tracking system and the predictive ordering algorithm are what they want detailed.
Right, the program. [sighs]

[formally] I've reviewed your preliminary notes about reducing food waste by forty-seven percent while improving nutritional density scores. [pause] The data modeling is actually quite sophisticated for a school cafeteria operation.

[quietly] Started working on it about five years ago when I noticed how much good food we were throwing away while kids went hungry on weekends. [slowly] The algorithm learns from consumption patterns and adjusts ordering automatically now.

[hesitantly] The timestamp logs show you've been iterating this system every single day for twenty months straight, including holidays. [very quietly] That's an unusual level of dedication for a school lunch program.
[bitter] Dedication's all I have.

[shaky voice] Mom said you moved to California after you left, said you were starting fresh with some tech company. [exhales] Never thought I'd find you serving lunch trays three miles from our old house.
California didn't work out. [long pause]

[anxious] Look, we need to document the API integration with the district's inventory system and I have a deadline tomorrow. [quickly] Can we just get through the technical specifications without making this more complicated than it needs to be?

[regretful] Every kid who comes through that lunch line reminds me of what I missed with you and your sister. [very quietly] The program started as penance, I guess, trying to feed other people's kids when I couldn't even stay for my own.

[firmly] The backend architecture uses a modified neural network for prediction modeling, and that's what my readers need to understand. [pause] Not whatever story you're trying to tell yourself about redemption.

[apologetic] You're right, I'm sorry, let's stick to the technical details about the system. [clearing throat] The neural network has three hidden layers with dropout regularization to prevent overfitting on seasonal menu variations.
[coldly] Mom died last year.

[whispering] I know, I saw the obituary online and wanted to come to the service but figured I'd lost that right twenty years ago. [shaky voice] Started sending anonymous donations to her favorite food bank instead.

[quietly] She kept every article I ever wrote in a binder by her hospital bed, including the one about automated systems replacing human connection. [bitter] Funny how that one feels relevant right now, discussing algorithms instead of addressing twenty years of silence.

[slowly] The system sends automated alerts when it detects a student hasn't eaten in two days, flags potential food insecurity cases for intervention. [very quietly] Technology doing what I couldn't—making sure no kid gets forgotten or left behind.
Let's finish this tomorrow. [sighs]

[hesitantly] There's something else about the program I haven't told anyone—it's tagged every student with your last name for priority meal access since I started. [whispering] Just in case you ever had kids who might need it.
